==Chinese==
{{zh-forms}}

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etyl}}
{{Han compound|宀|t1=roof|各|ls=psc|c1=s|c2=p}} – a guest. Oracle bone script used {{och-l|𠯆}} instead of {{zh-l|*各}}.

===Etymology===
Probably belongs to the word family of {{och-l|格|to go, to come}}. Starostin compares this with {{cog|tut-pro|*kàra||opposite, enemy}} > {{cog|tr|karak||robber}}. {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} cites {{cog|bo|དགྲ||enemy}} as a possible cognate.

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|きゃく}}

# [[guest]]
# [[customer]]
# [[patron]]

====Usage notes====
This is used as part of a form of address for a customer, like [[sir]] or [[ma'am]]. Because a customer is in a much higher social position, this word is used with the honorific prefix {{l|ja|御|tr=お, o-}} and the honorific suffix {{l|ja|さん|tr=-san}} or more often {{l|ja|さま|tr=-sama}}, rendering お客さん (''okyakusan'') or お客様 (''okyakusama'').
